So @mtrichardson I can has your java server?
I bet python could do 500k; the main ingredient wasn't Java, it was lowering memory usage in the kernel. But dealing with 500k connections efficiently in CPython would definitely be harder.

You'd definitely want something that did epoll at the bottom, and the server @cscotta built in Java makes very good use of threads for support tasks. I'm curious, though, how much of those would be unduly penalized by the GIL in practice.

To @alex's point earlier... I've heard some recent high-praise for C#. Anyone with experience care to comment?
... in a new comment, perhaps?
s/comment/topic/

@justinlilly I mucked around with it a *very* small amount since a friend of mine's high school class was using it.  I wasn't overly impressed felt a lot like java.  I'm told there's nice stuff at the high-end though so I guess that's where the wins are.
@justinlilly A friend of mine uses C# daily and moved to it from Java (previous job). He claims it's considerably better than Java and really enjoys working in it.
There was a thread at work which was basically "Every java programmer should learn about C# so you know what you're missing out on"
Out here on the wild plains of the Web, we shrug off both those languages a lot ;)
That should probably tell you something.
@davisp that "considerably better than java" just ain't that great
"considerably better than java" with regards to concurrency.
Not that great?
"considerably better than java" with regards to tool support
There is quite a lot that java has going for it, even if its not something you value highly.
I won't dispute concurrency, but half of the java tooling is to support how craptastic the language is
well, concurrency isn't even that interesting as a language feature, Java is a horrible language with a really good implementation
*shrug* Merely saying that something being "better than java" isn't a marker for failure. Its all about your frame of reference.
I am sure he could give details, but from a day to day "spending time in and using X language" C# has been a significant improvement according to him.
invite him :)
Granted there could be some improvements to the language to make more people appreciate/get excited about it.
@alex I'd disagree with that concurrency as a language feature isn't interesting. Erlang's process/supervision trees model is superb in my opinion
I kinda like Go and its similarities, but its missing the supervision tree aspects.
@davisp Agree. It's really nice when components can crash independently and the built-in supervisor behavior is siiick.
i swear i'll learn erlang and scala by the end of the year and be terrible at both. hurray for solid resolutions!
@tilgovi Yeah, I really like crash only design
Also, I would agree with @tilgovi that Java's "concurrency as a language feature" is actually more of a "slightly abstract API over mutexes"
